The '''CHIPS and Science Act''' is a U.S. federal statute enacted by the [[117th United States Congress]] and signed into law by President [[Joe Biden]] on August 9, 2022. The act provides roughly $280 billion in new funding to boost domestic research and manufacturing of [[semiconductors]] in the United States.<ref name="Politico 20220809">{{Cite web |last=Johnson |first=Lamar |date=August 9, 2022 |title=Biden ends slog on semiconductor bill with signature |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/08/09/biden-ends-slog-on-semiconductor-bill-with-signature-00050530 |access-date=August 9, 2022 |website=[[POLITICO]] |language=en |quote=Biden said Micron, an American-based company, announced a 10-year, $40 billion investment on Tuesday for factories and building memory chips as a result of the law. He also touted a Monday announcement by American companies Qualcomm and GlobalFoundries to invest $4 billion to produce semiconductors in the United States. |archive-date=August 21, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220821173945/https://www.politico.com/news/2022/08/09/biden-ends-slog-on-semiconductor-bill-with-signature-00050530 |url-status=live }}</ref> 
The act includes $39 billion in subsidies for chip manufacturing on US soil along with 25% investment tax credits for costs of manufacturing equipment, and $13 billion for semiconductor research and workforce training, with the primary aim of countering China.<ref name="Economist_2023-03-06">{{Cite news |date=2023-03-06 |title=Taiwan's dominance of the chip industry makes it more important – No industry matters more to Taiwan than chipmaking |work=[[The Economist]] |url=https://www.economist.com/special-report/2023/03/06/taiwans-dominance-of-the-chip-industry-makes-it-more-important |url-status=live |quote=America is also trying to stop China getting advanced chips. It passed the CHIPS and Science Act in August 2022, offering $39bn in subsidies and a 25% tax credit to promote manufacturing at home, as well as $13bn of investment in chip research. In October 2022 it banned the export of advanced chips and chipmaking gear to China. |access-date=March 11, 2023 |archive-date=March 11, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230311010040/https://www.economist.com/special-report/2023/03/06/taiwans-dominance-of-the-chip-industry-makes-it-more-important }}</ref>{{ r | SJMN_2022-09-04 | p=1 | q=The CHIPS and Science Act aims to create a new world order. The $280 billion package includes $39 billion to help with the financing of semiconductor fabrication, assembly, testing and advanced packaging, as well as $13.2 billion toward research and workforce development. It also provides a 25% investment tax credit for capital costs of manufacturing equipment. }}

The act does not have an official short title as a whole but is divided into three divisions with their own short titles: Division A is the '''CHIPS Act of 2022''' (where CHIPS stands for "Creating Helpful Incentives to Produce Semiconductors"); Division B is the '''Research and Development, Competition, and Innovation Act'''; and Division C is the '''Supreme Court Security Funding Act of 2022'''.<ref>{{Cite web |date=August 9, 2022 |title=Text – H.R.4346 – 117th Congress (2021–2022): Supreme Court Security Funding Act of 2022 |url=http://www.congress.gov/ |access-date=2022-09-11 |website=U.S. Congress |archive-date=May 17, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200517224927/http://www.congress.gov/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

== History ==
The '''CHIPS and Science Act''' combines two bipartisan bills: the '''Endless Frontier Act''',<ref>{{Cite web |title=Congressional Bill |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/3832 |access-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-date=November 27, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221127192918/https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/3832 |url-status=live }}</ref> designed to boost investment in domestic high-tech research and the '''CHIPS for America Act''',<ref>{{Cite web |title=Congressional Bill |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/7178 |access-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162755/https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/7178 |url-status=live }}</ref> designed to bring semiconductor manufacturing back to the U.S. The act is aimed at competing with China.<ref>{{Cite journal |date=2014 |title=Bipartisan support for US science more likely in Senate than House |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/pt.5.028154 |journal=Physics Today |doi=10.1063/pt.5.028154 |issn=1945-0699 |access-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-date=May 3, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230503215855/https://pubs.aip.org/physicstoday/Online/6419/Bipartisan-support-for-US-science-more-likely-in |url-status=live }}</ref>

The '''Endless Frontier Act''' was initially presented to Senators [[Chuck Schumer]] (D-NY) and [[Todd Young]] (R-IN) by [[United States Under Secretary of State|Under Secretary of State]] [[Keith J. Krach|Keith Krach]] in October 2019, as part of the Global Economic Security Strategy to boost investment in high-tech research vital to U.S. national security.<ref>{{Cite web |date=March 21, 2022 |title=Purdue Center for Tech Diplomacy Chairman Keith Krach and Director Bonnie Glick Counsel Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo on Securing Semiconductor Supply Chain |url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20220321005892/en/Purdue-Center-for-Tech-Diplomacy-Chairman-Keith-Krach-and-Director-Bonnie-Glick-Counsel-Commerce-Secretary-Gina-Raimondo-on-Securing-Semiconductor-Supply-Chain |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=www.businesswire.com |language=en |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162755/https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20220321005892/en/Purdue-Center-for-Tech-Diplomacy-Chairman-Keith-Krach-and-Director-Bonnie-Glick-Counsel-Commerce-Secretary-Gina-Raimondo-on-Securing-Semiconductor-Supply-Chain |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Krach">{{Cite web |last=Krach |first=Keith |date=June 17, 2021 |title=The Senate just passed the next Apollo program |url=https://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/technology/559065-the-senate-just-passed-the-next-apollo-program/ |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=The Hill |language=en-US |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162755/https://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/technology/559065-the-senate-just-passed-the-next-apollo-program/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The plan was to grow $150 billion in government R&D funding into a $500 billion investment, with matching investments from the private sector and a coalition of technological allies dubbed the "Techno-Democracies-10" (TD-10).<ref>{{Cite web |title=Read @Kearney: The US–China high-tech competition is modernizing American industries: an interview with Keith Krach |url=https://www.kearney.com/technology/article/-/insights/the-us-china-high-tech-competition-is-modernizing-american-industries-an-interview-with-keith-krach |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=Kearney |language=en |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162801/https://www.kearney.com/technology/article/-/insights/the-us-china-high-tech-competition-is-modernizing-american-industries-an-interview-with-keith-krach |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Krach" /> On May 27, 2020, Senators Young and Schumer, along with Congressmen [[Ro Khanna]] (D-CA) and [[Mike Gallagher (American politician)|Mike Gallagher]] (R-WI.), introduced the bipartisan, bicameral '''Endless Frontier Act''' to solidify the United States’ leadership in scientific and technological innovation through increased investments in the discovery, creation, and commercialization of technology fields of the future.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Young, Schumer Unveil Endless Frontier Act to Bolster U.S. Tech Leadership and Combat China {{!}} U.S. Senator Todd Young of Indiana |url=https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/young-schumer-unveil-endless-frontier-act-to-bolster-us-tech-leadership-and-combat-china |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=www.young.senate.gov |language=en |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162756/https://www.young.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/young-schumer-unveil-endless-frontier-act-to-bolster-us-tech-leadership-and-combat-china |url-status=live }}</ref>

The '''United States Innovation and Competition Act of 2021 (USICA)''' (S. 1260), formerly known as the Endless Frontier Act, was United States legislation sponsored by [[Party leaders of the United States Senate|Senate Majority Leader]] Chuck Schumer and Senator Young authorizing $110 billion for basic and advanced technology research over a five-year period. Investment in basic and advanced research, commercialization, and education and training programs in [[artificial intelligence]], [[semiconductor]]s, [[quantum computing]], advanced communications, [[biotechnology]] and advanced energy, amounts to $100 billion. Over $10 billion was authorized for appropriation to designate ten regional technology hubs and create a [[supply chain crisis]]-response program.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Endless Frontier Act: Shifting the Focus from Defense to Offense |url=https://www.natlawreview.com/article/endless-frontier-act-shifting-focus-defense-to-offense |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=The National Law Review |language=en |archive-date=May 13, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210513090302/https://www.natlawreview.com/article/endless-frontier-act-shifting-focus-defense-to-offense |url-status=live }}</ref>

The CHIPS for America Act portion stemmed from Under Secretary of State Krach and his team brokering the $12 billion on-shoring of [[TSMC]] (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company) to secure the supply chain of sophisticated semiconductors, on May 15, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Ip |first=Greg |title='Industrial Policy' Is Back: The West Dusts Off Old Idea to Counter China |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/subsidies-chips-china-state-aid-biden-11627565906 |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=WSJ |language=en-US |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162755/https://www.wsj.com/articles/subsidies-chips-china-state-aid-biden-11627565906 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Briefing with Under Secretary for Growth, Energy, and the Environment Keith Krach, Science and Technology Adviser to the Secretary Mung Chiang, and Assistant Secretary for International Security and Nonproliferation Christopher A. Ford On Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation's Intent to Invest $12 Billion In the U.S. and on the CCP's Ability to Undermine U.S. Export Controls |url=https://2017-2021.state.gov/briefing-with-under-secretary-for-growth-energy-and-the-environment-keith-krach-science-and-technology-adviser-to-the-secretary-mung-chiang-and-assistant-secretary-for-international-security-and-n/ |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=United States Department of State |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=US woos Taiwan and its chipmakers in step toward trade pact |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/International-relations/US-China-tensions/US-woos-Taiwan-and-its-chipmakers-in-step-toward-trade-pact |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=Nikkei Asia |language=en-GB |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162759/https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/International-relations/US-China-tensions/US-woos-Taiwan-and-its-chipmakers-in-step-toward-trade-pact |url-status=live }}</ref> Krach's stated strategy was to use the [[TSMC]] announcement as a stimulus for fortifying a trusted supply chain by attracting TSMC's broad ecosystem of suppliers; persuading other chip companies to produce in U.S., especially Intel and Samsung; inspiring universities to develop engineering curricula focused on semiconductor manufacturing and designing a bipartisan bill (CHIPS for America) to provide the necessary funding.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web |last=Patterson |first=Alan |date=August 1, 2022 |title=Architect of CHIPS Act Speaks on Its Impact |url=https://www.eetimes.com/architect-of-chips-act-speaks-on-its-impact/ |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=EE Times |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162801/https://www.eetimes.com/architect-of-chips-act-speaks-on-its-impact/ |url-status=live }}</ref> This led to Krach and his team's close collaboration in creating the CHIPS for America component with Senators [[John Cornyn]] (R-TX) and [[Mark Warner]] (D-VA).<ref>{{Cite web |title=Purdue Center for Tech Diplomacy Chairman Keith Krach and Director Bonnie Glick Counsel Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo on Securing Semiconductor Supply Chain |url=https://www.yahoo.com/now/purdue-center-tech-diplomacy-chairman-224100125.html |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=www.yahoo.com |language=en-US |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162756/https://www.yahoo.com/now/purdue-center-tech-diplomacy-chairman-224100125.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In June 2020, Senator Warner joined U.S. Senator John Cornyn in introducing the $52 billion CHIPS for America Act.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hamblen |first=Matt |date=August 9, 2022 |title=President Biden signs CHIPS and Science Act: comments and reactions |language=en |work=Fierce Electronics |url=https://www.fierceelectronics.com/sensors/president-biden-signs-chips-and-science-act-comments-and-reactions |access-date=2023-01-05 |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162759/https://www.fierceelectronics.com/sensors/president-biden-signs-chips-and-science-act-comments-and-reactions |url-status=live }}</ref>

Both bills were eventually merged into the [[United States Innovation and Competition Act|U.S. Innovation and Competition Act]] (USICA). On June 8, 2021, the USICA passed 68–32 in the Senate with bipartisan support. The House version of the Bill, [[America COMPETES Act#America COMPETES Act of 2022|America COMPETES Act of 2022]] (H.R. 4521), passed on February 4, 2022. The Senate passed an amended bill by substituting the text of H.R. 4521 with the text of the USICA on March 28, 2022. A Senate and House conference was required to reconcile the differences, which resulted in the bipartisan '''CHIPS and Science Act''', or "CHIPS Plus".<ref>{{Cite web |date=July 27, 2022 |title=The Bipartisan CHIPS Act—and a United U.S.— Are China's Biggest Fear |url=https://www.newsweek.com/bipartisan-chips-act-united-us-are-chinas-biggest-fear-opinion-1728573 |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=Newsweek |language=en |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162756/https://www.newsweek.com/bipartisan-chips-act-united-us-are-chinas-biggest-fear-opinion-1728573 |url-status=live }}</ref> The bill passed the [[U.S. Senate]] by a vote of 64–33 on July 27, 2022.<ref name="Sprunt 1" /> On July 28, the $280 billion bill passed the [[U.S. House]] by a vote of 243–187–1.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Kelly |first=Makena |date=July 28, 2022 |title=CHIPS Act clears Congress, ensuring $52 billion boost to US foundries |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/7/28/23282494/semiconductors-chips-and-science-act-joe-biden-congress-nvidia |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=The Verge |language=en-US |archive-date=September 1, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220901231113/https://www.theverge.com/2022/7/28/23282494/semiconductors-chips-and-science-act-joe-biden-congress-nvidia |url-status=live }}</ref> On August 1, 2022, the magazine ''[[EE Times]]'' (Electronic Engineering) dubbed Under Secretary of State [[Keith J. Krach|Keith Krach]] ({{as of|2023|02|lc=y}}, now the current Chairman of the Krach Institute for Tech Diplomacy at [[Purdue University]]) the architect of the CHIPS and Science Act.<ref name=":02" /> The bill was signed into law by President [[Joe Biden]] on August 9, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-08-09 |title=Remarks by President Biden at Signing of H.R. 4346, "The CHIPS and Science Act of 2022" |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2022/08/09/remarks-by-president-biden-at-signing-of-h-r-4346-the-chips-and-science-act-of-2022/ |access-date=2023-05-03 |website=The White House |language=en-US |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162759/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2022/08/09/remarks-by-president-biden-at-signing-of-h-r-4346-the-chips-and-science-act-of-2022/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Background and provisions ==
The bill constitutes an industrial policy initiative which takes place against the background of a perceived [[Artificial Intelligence Cold War|AI Cold War]] between the US and China, as [[artificial intelligence]] technology relies on semiconductors.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Herman |first=Arthur |date=17 October 2022 |title=The Chip War With China Is Just Getting Started |work=Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/arthurherman/2022/10/17/the-chip-war-with-china-is-just-getting-started/?sh=4224c4346a08 |access-date=8 January 2023 |archive-date=January 8, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230108111903/https://www.forbes.com/sites/arthurherman/2022/10/17/the-chip-war-with-china-is-just-getting-started/?sh=4224c4346a08 |url-status=live }}</ref> The bill was considered amidst a [[2020–present global chip shortage|global semiconductor shortage]] and intended to provide subsidies and tax credits to chip makers with operations in the United States. The [[U.S. Department of Commerce]] was granted the power to allocate funds based on companies' willingness to sustain research, build facilities, and train new workers.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Swanson |first=Ana |date=August 3, 2022 |title=Congress Is Giving Billions to the Chip Industry. Strings Are Attached. |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/03/business/economy/chip-industry-congress.html |url-access=subscription |access-date=August 5, 2022 |archive-date=October 21, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221021051739/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/08/03/business/economy/chip-industry-congress.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

For semiconductor and telecommunications purposes, the CHIPS Act designates roughly $106 billion. The CHIPS Act includes $39 billion in tax benefits and other incentives to encourage American companies to build new chip manufacturing plants in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web |title=What's in the recently passed CHIPS Act? |url=https://usafacts.org/articles/whats-in-the-recently-passed-chips-act/ |access-date=2022-08-15 |website=USAFacts |language=en |archive-date=October 15, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221015070104/https://usafacts.org/articles/whats-in-the-recently-passed-chips-act/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Additionally, $11 billion would go toward advanced semiconductor research and development, with $8.5 billion of that amount going to the [[National Institute for Standards and Technology]], $500 million to [[Manufacturing USA]], and $2 billion to a new public research hub called the National Semiconductor Technology Center. $24 billion would go to a new 25 percent advanced semiconductor manufacturing tax credit to encourage firms to stay in the United States, and $200 million would go to the [[National Science Foundation]] to resolve short-term labor supply issues.<ref name="McKinsey 2022" /><ref name="CSIS 2022" />

According to [[McKinsey]], "The CHIPS Act allocates $2 billion to the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] to fund microelectronics research, fabrication, and workforce training. An additional $500 million goes to the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] to coordinate with foreign-government partners on semiconductor supply chain security. And $1.5 billion funds the USA Telecommunications Act of 2020, which aims to enhance competitiveness of software and hardware supply chains of open [[radio access network|RAN]] [[5G]] networks."<ref name="McKinsey 2022">{{Cite web |last=Badlam |first=Justin |last2=Clark |first2=Stephen |last3=Gajendragakar |first3=Suhrid |last4=Kumar |first4=Adi |last5=O’Rourke |first5=Sara |last6=Swartz |first6=Dale |date=October 4, 2022 |title=The CHIPS and Science Act: Here's what's in it |url=https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/public-and-social-sector/our-insights/the-chips-and-science-act-heres-whats-in-it |access-date=October 5, 2022 |website=McKinsey & Company |archive-date=October 5, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221005070010/https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/public-and-social-sector/our-insights/the-chips-and-science-act-heres-whats-in-it |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="CSIS 2022">{{Cite journal |last=Kersten |first=Alexander |last2=Athanasia |first2=Gabrielle |last3=Arcuri |first3=Gregory |date=August 9, 2022 |title=A Look at the CHIPS-Related Portions of CHIPS+ |url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/look-chips-related-portions-chips |access-date=October 5, 2022 |website=Center for Strategic and International Studies |archive-date=October 5, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221005151524/https://www.csis.org/analysis/look-chips-related-portions-chips |url-status=live }}</ref> Companies are subjected to a ten-year ban prohibiting them from producing chips more advanced than 28-nanometers in China and Russia if they are awarded subsidies under the act.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Debby Wu |last2=Daniel Flatley |last3=Jenny Leonard |date=August 2, 2022 |title=US to Stop TSMC, Intel From Adding Advanced Chip Fabs in China |work=Bloomberg |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-08-02/us-to-stop-tsmc-intel-from-adding-advanced-chip-fabs-in-china |access-date=August 13, 2022 |archive-date=May 3, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230503215915/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-08-02/us-to-stop-tsmc-intel-from-adding-advanced-chip-fabs-in-china |url-status=live }}</ref>

The act authorizes $174 billion for uses other than semiconductor and telecom technologies.<ref name="McKinsey 2022" /><ref name="CSIS 2 2022" /> It authorizes, but does not appropriate, extended [[NASA]] funding for the [[International Space Station]] to 2030, partially funds the [[Artemis program]] returning humans to the Moon, and directs NASA to establish a Moon to Mars Program Office for a [[human mission to Mars]] beyond the Artemis program. The bill also obligates NASA to perform research into further domesticating its supply chains and diversifying and developing its workforce, reducing the [[environmental effects of aviation]], integrating [[unmanned aerial vehicle]] detection with [[air traffic control]], investigating [[nuclear propulsion]] for spacecraft, continuing the [[search for extraterrestrial intelligence]] and [[xenology]] efforts, and boosting [[astronomical survey]]s for [[Near-Earth object]]s including the [[NEO Surveyor]] project.<ref name="Politico 20220809" /><ref name="Errick 2022">{{Cite web |last=Errick |first=Kirsten |date=August 4, 2022 |title=NASA Authorization Act Aims to Strengthen U.S. Space Exploration |url=https://www.nextgov.com/emerging-tech/2022/08/nasa-authorization-act-aims-strengthen-us-space-exploration/375394/ |access-date=August 24, 2022 |website=Nextgov.com |archive-date=August 24, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220824021158/https://www.nextgov.com/emerging-tech/2022/08/nasa-authorization-act-aims-strengthen-us-space-exploration/375394/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

The bill could potentially invest $67 billion in accelerating advanced zero-emissions technologies to mass markets and improving [[climate science]] research, according to the climate action think tank [[Rocky Mountain Institute]]. The bill would invest $81 billion in the NSF, including new money for [[STEM]] education and defense against foreign [[intellectual property infringement]], and $20 billion in the new Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships, which would be tasked with deploying the above technologies, and authorizes but does not appropriate $12 billion for [[ARPA-E]].<ref name="Atlantic 20220810">{{Cite web |last=Meyer |first=Robinson |date=August 10, 2022 |title=Congress Just Passed a Big Climate Bill. No, Not That One. |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2022/08/chips-act-climate-bill-biden/671095/ |access-date=2022-10-05 |website=The Atlantic |archive-date=October 5, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221005151524/https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2022/08/chips-act-climate-bill-biden/671095/ |url-status=live }}</ref> It contains annual budget increases for the [[United States Department of Energy]] for other purposes including [[supercomputer]], [[nuclear fusion]] and [[particle accelerator]] research, and directs the [[United States Department of Commerce]] to establish $10 billion worth of research hubs in post-industrial, mostly rural economies.<ref name="McKinsey 2022" /><ref name="CSIS 2 2022">{{Cite journal |last=Arcuri |first=Gregory |last2=Shivakumar |first2=Sujai |date=August 11, 2022 |title=A Look at the Science-Related Portions of CHIPS+ |url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/look-science-related-portions-chips |access-date=October 5, 2022 |website=Center for Strategic and International Studies |archive-date=October 5, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221005151534/https://www.csis.org/analysis/look-science-related-portions-chips |url-status=live }}</ref>

B. === Opposition ===
The bill was criticized by Republican House leader [[Kevin McCarthy]] and senator [[Bernie Sanders]] as a "blank check", which the latter equated to a bribe to semiconductor companies.<ref name="Sprunt 1" /><ref name="verge-clears-congress">{{Cite news |last=Kelly |first=Makena |date=July 28, 2022 |title=CHIPS Act clears Congress, ensuring $52 billion boost to US foundries |work=The Verge |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/7/28/23282494/semiconductors-chips-and-science-act-joe-biden-congress-nvidia |access-date=August 5, 2022 |archive-date=September 1, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220901231113/https://www.theverge.com/2022/7/28/23282494/semiconductors-chips-and-science-act-joe-biden-congress-nvidia |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=NEWS: Sanders Opposes All Blank Checks to Chip Companies » Senator Bernie Sanders |url=https://www.sanders.senate.gov/press-releases/news-sanders-opposes-all-blank-checks-to-chip-companies/ |access-date=2022-09-09 |website=Senator Bernie Sanders |language=en-US |archive-date=September 9, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220909122507/https://www.sanders.senate.gov/press-releases/news-sanders-opposes-all-blank-checks-to-chip-companies/ |url-status=live }}</ref> China lobbied against the bill and criticized it as being "reminiscent of a 'Cold War mentality{{'"}}.<ref>{{Cite web |last=O'Meara |first=Sean |date=July 29, 2022 |title=China Says US Chip Act Will Harm Supply Chain, Global Trade |url=https://www.asiafinancial.com/china-says-us-chip-act-will-harm-supply-chain-global-trade |access-date=2022-08-09 |website=Asia Financial |language=en-US |archive-date=August 25, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220825201518/https://www.asiafinancial.com/china-says-us-chip-act-will-harm-supply-chain-global-trade |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== Concerns of protectionism ===
Commentators{{who|date=January 2023}} have expressed concerns regarding the protectionist provisions of the CHIPS and Science Act and the risk of a subsidy race with the [[EU]], which proposed its own [[European Chips Act]] in 2022.<ref name="Brookings">{{Cite news |last=Timmers |first=Paul |last2=Kreps |first2=Sarah |date=20 December 2022 |title=Bringing economics back into EU and U.S. chips policy |work=Brookings |url=https://www.brookings.edu/techstream/bringing-economics-back-into-the-politics-of-the-eu-and-u-s-chips-acts-china-semiconductor-competition/ |access-date=8 January 2023 |archive-date=January 8, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230108121604/https://www.brookings.edu/techstream/bringing-economics-back-into-the-politics-of-the-eu-and-u-s-chips-acts-china-semiconductor-competition/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

===Concerns of inaction on labor and stock buybacks===
[[Robert Kuttner]], [[economic nationalist]] commentator and editor of ''[[The American Prospect]]'', expressed concerns that the bill did not provide enough resources to allow local residents near fabs to organize or form a [[trade union]] (thereby making unions rely too heavily on [[community benefits agreement]]s compared to federal policy), that the Commerce Department would be too friendly to states with [[right-to-work law]]s (where the first new fabs would be built), that the bill did not restrictively define a "domestic company" regarding financing, and that fab owners would simply use CHIPS Act money to [[Share repurchase|buy back stocks]].<ref name="Kuttner 2023">{{Cite web |last=Kuttner |first=Robert |date=January 24, 2023 |title=Reclaiming U.S. Industry == Impact ==
Since the May 2020 onshoring of TSMC used by Under Secretary of State [[Keith J. Krach]] as a catalyst for the bill and to secure the U.S. semiconductor supply chain, a significant number of companies and a list of ecosystem suppliers have committed or made announcements for investments and jobs in the US.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Krach |first=Keith |last2=Hormats |first2=Bob |date=December 21, 2022 |title=Funding the CHIPS and Science Act is a national security imperative |url=https://thehill.com/opinion/technology/3782796-funding-the-chips-and-science-act-is-a-national-security-imperative/ |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=The Hill |language=en-US |archive-date=January 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230105162756/https://thehill.com/opinion/technology/3782796-funding-the-chips-and-science-act-is-a-national-security-imperative/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=":02" />

By 2030, the company expects to occupy more than one million square feet of manufacturing space across 445 acres, at a cost of $1.3 billion.  The first phase of development is supported by approximately $1 billion in incentives from state, county, and local governments, and the company intends to apply for CHIPS act money.<ref>{{Cite news |date=September 9, 2022 |title=Wolfspeed Selects North Carolina for World's Largest Silicon Carbide Materials Facility |language=en-US |work=Wolfspeed press release |url=https://www.wolfspeed.com/company/news-events/news/wolfspeed-selects-north-carolina-for-worlds-largest-silicon-carbide-materials-facility/ |access-date=2023-04-17 |quote=In addition, the company hopes to apply for and obtain federal funding from the CHIPS and Science Act to accelerate the construction and build-out of the facility. |archive-date=April 17, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230417210901/https://www.wolfspeed.com/company/news-events/news/wolfspeed-selects-north-carolina-for-worlds-largest-silicon-carbide-materials-facility/ |url-status=live }}</ref> 

* In October 2022, [[Micron Technology]] announced it will invest $20 billion in a new chip factory in [[Clay, New York]], to take advantages of the subsidies in the act and signaled it could expand its investments to $100 billion over 20 years.{{ r | Politico 20220809 }}<ref name="WaPo_2022-10-04">{{Cite news |title=Chipmaker Micron to build $20 billion N.Y. factory amid semiconductor boom |language=en-US |work=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/04/micron-chip-factory-new-york/ |access-date=2022-10-05 |issn=0190-8286 |quote=New York is giving Micron $5.5 billion in tax credits over the life of the project if the company meets certain employment targets. |archive-date=October 6, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221006002244/https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/04/micron-chip-factory-new-york/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Lohr |first=Steve |date=October 4, 2022 |title=Micron Pledges Up to $100 Billion for Semiconductor Factory in New York |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/04/technology/micron-chip-clay-syracuse.html |access-date=2022-10-06 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=October 6, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221006000024/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/04/technology/micron-chip-clay-syracuse.html |url-status=live }}</ref>  The state of New York granted the company $5.5 billion in [[tax credits]] as an incentive to locate there, if it meets employment promises.{{ r | WaPo_2022-10-04 }}
* In December 2022, TSMC announced the opening of the company's second chip plant in [[Arizona]], raising its investments in the state from $12 billion to $40 billion.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Kinery |first=Emma |title=TSMC to up Arizona investment to $40 billion with second semiconductor chip plant |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/12/06/tsmc-to-up-arizona-investment-to-40-billion-with-second-semiconductor-chip-plant.html |access-date=2023-01-05 |website=CNBC |language=en |archive-date=January 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230106112439/https://www.cnbc.com/2022/12/06/tsmc-to-up-arizona-investment-to-40-billion-with-second-semiconductor-chip-plant.html |url-status=live }}</ref> At that time, they also stated that they were running into major cost issues, because the cost of construction of buildings and facilities in the US is four to five times what an identical plant would cost in Taiwan, (due to higher costs of labor, red tape, and training), as well as difficulty finding qualified personnel (for which it has hired US workers and sent them for training in Taiwan for 12-18 months.) These additional production costs will increase the cost of TSMC's chips made in the US to at least 50% more than the cost of chips made in Taiwan.<ref name="WSJ_2022-12-05">{{Cite news |last=Jie |first=Yang |date=2022-12-05 |title=TSMC's Arizona Chip Plant, Awaiting Biden Visit, Faces Birthing Pains - Taiwanese company cites high costs and shortage of skilled personnel as it pushes to open $12 billion factory next year |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/tsmcs-arizona-chip-plant-awaiting-biden-visit-faces-birthing-pains-11670236129?mod=Searchresults_pos2&page=1 |quote=Mr. Biden has been pushing to bring more high-tech manufacturing to the U.S. In August, he signed a law that includes $52 billion in direct aid for building semiconductor plants, which lawmakers viewed as key to ensuring American technology leadership and securing supply chains. ... Mr. Chang said the cost of making chips in Arizona may be at least 50% higher than in Taiwan. |access-date=March 3, 2023 |archive-date=March 3, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230303023453/https://www.wsj.com/articles/tsmcs-arizona-chip-plant-awaiting-biden-visit-faces-birthing-pains-11670236129?mod=Searchresults_pos2&page=1 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Noah_SS">{{Cite web |last=Smith |first=Noah |author-link=Noah Smith (writer) |date=2023-02-07 |title=The Build-Nothing Country - Stasis has become America's spoils system, and it can't go on. |url=https://noahpinion.substack.com/p/the-build-nothing-country?sd=pf |quote=TSMC, the Taiwanese company that recently agreed to build a big plant in Arizona, is running into major cost issues: |access-date=March 3, 2023 |archive-date=March 3, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230303023452/https://noahpinion.substack.com/p/the-build-nothing-country?sd=pf |url-status=live }}</ref>
* In February 2023, [[Texas Instruments]] announced an $11 billion investment in a new 300-mm wafer fab in [[Lehi, Utah]].<ref name="Clarke 2023">{{Cite web |last=Clarke |first=Kaitlyn |date=February 15, 2023 |title=Texas Instruments To Build New Chip Factory in Lehi, Bringing Hundreds of Jobs to the State |url=https://business.utah.gov/tax-credits/texas-instruments-to-build-new-chip-factory-in-lehi-bringing-hundreds-of-jobs-to-the-state/ |access-date=March 9, 2023 |website=business.utah.gov |archive-date=March 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230309202429/https://business.utah.gov/tax-credits/texas-instruments-to-build-new-chip-factory-in-lehi-bringing-hundreds-of-jobs-to-the-state/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
* In February 2023, [[Integra Technologies]] announced a $1.8 billion proposal for expanding their Outsourced Semiconductor Assembly and Test (OSAT) operation in [[Wichita, Kansas]].<ref name="Wichita 2023">{{Cite web |date=February 2, 2023 |title=Governor Kelly Announces Integra Technologies to Invest $1.8B, Create Nearly 2,000 Jobs with Wichita Semiconductor Plant |url=https://www.kansascommerce.gov/2023/02/governor-kelly-announces-integra-technologies-to-invest-1-8b-create-nearly-2000-jobs-with-wichita-semiconductor-plant/ |access-date=March 9, 2023 |website=Kansas Department of Commerce |archive-date=March 7, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230307092324/https://www.kansascommerce.gov/2023/02/governor-kelly-announces-integra-technologies-to-invest-1-8b-create-nearly-2000-jobs-with-wichita-semiconductor-plant/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

There are many others too.<ref name="Conness 2022"/><ref name="Ravi Casanova 2022"/>

The trade group [[Semiconductor Industry Association]] conducted an analysis of announced investments from May 2020 to December 2022, claiming the CHIPS Act incentivized $200 billion worth of over 50 projects creating a predicted 44,000 new jobs.<ref name="Ravi Casanova 2022">{{Cite web |last=Ravi |first=Sarah |last2=Casanova |first2=Robert |date=December 14, 2022 |title=The CHIPS Act Has Already Sparked $200 Billion in Private Investments for U.S. Semiconductor Production |url=https://www.semiconductors.org/the-chips-act-has-already-sparked-200-billion-in-private-investments-for-u-s-semiconductor-production/ |access-date=May 1, 2023 |website=Semiconductor Industry Association |archive-date=March 30, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230330085952/https://www.semiconductors.org/the-chips-act-has-already-sparked-200-billion-in-private-investments-for-u-s-semiconductor-production/ |url-status=live }}</ref> However, independent policy researcher Jack Conness said that the CHIPS Act incentivized $151 billion worth of 26 projects creating a predicted 21,400 jobs, {{as of|2023|05|23|lc=y}}. Due to the Act's incentives Arizona would receive the largest individual investment (the $40 billion from TSMC creating 4,500 projected jobs) and the most dollars overall ($70.5 billion), followed by Oklahoma for individual investments (the $20 billion from Micron creating 3,000 projected jobs) and New York for overall dollars ($40.3 billion).<ref name="Conness 2022">{{Cite web |date=May 23, 2023 |title=Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) and CHIPS and Science Act Investments |url=https://www.jackconness.com/ira-chips-investments |access-date=May 24, 2023 |website=Jack Conness |archive-date=May 24, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230524064953/https://www.jackconness.com/ira-chips-investments |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2023/04/house-republicans-debt-ceiling-clean-energy-ira-irs-joe-biden/|title=House Republicans Are Playing Debt-Ceiling Russian Roulette|last=Mechanic|first=Michael|website=[[Mother Jones (magazine)]]|date=April 27, 2023|access-date=May 6, 2023}}</ref><ref name="Jenkins 2023">{{Cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2023/04/electrify-everything-scope-data/|first=Jesse D.|last=Jenkins|title=What “Electrify Everything” Actually Looks Like|date=May 2023|access-date=May 8, 2023|website=[[Mother Jones (magazine)]]}}</ref><ref name="Dayen 2023">{{cite web | last=Dayen | first=David | title=A Liberalism That Builds Power | website=[[The American Prospect]] | date=May 25, 2023 | url=https://prospect.org/api/content/4746efa0-fa57-11ed-a84c-12163087a831/ | access-date=May 26, 2023}}</ref>

===California===
In [[California]], home to the birthplace of the semiconductor industry, [[Silicon Valley]], experts say that it is very unlikely that any new manufacturing facilities will be built, due to tight regulations, high costs of land and electricity, and unreliable water supplies.<ref name="SJMN_2022-09-04">{{Cite news |last=Krieger |first=Lisa |date=2022-09-04 |title=The U.S. is bringing chip-making home. Is California ready? - What the $52.7 billion CHIPS Act might mean for the birthplace of technology |work=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2022/09/04/the-u-s-is-bringing-chip-making-home-is-california-ready/ |quote=But experts say that new plants are unlikely to be erected here. Manufacturing is stifled by several factors: high real-estate costs, unreliable water, expensive electric bills and stiff regulations. In general, manufacturing has plummeted in California. Since 1990, the state has lost a third of its factory jobs. |access-date=March 14, 2023 |archive-date=March 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230314005744/https://www.mercurynews.com/2022/09/04/the-u-s-is-bringing-chip-making-home-is-california-ready/ |url-status=live }}</ref> These factors have contributed to the state's 33% decline in manufacturing jobs since 1990.{{ r | SJMN_2022-09-04 }}
